document_metadata.name: Cotinine: a potential new therapeutic agent against Alzheimer's disease

citation.name: Cotinine: a potential new therapeutic agent against Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: The progressive loss of memory in AD patients correlates with increased levels of Abeta and the deterioration of the cholinergic system in the brain.

citation.name: Cotinine: a potential new therapeutic agent against Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: This deterioration commonly includes a reduction in the levels of acetylcholine (ACh) and alpha3, alpha4, and alpha7 nicotinic ACh receptors (nAChRs) as well as a decrease in the activity of choline acetyltranferase in the brain [5].

citation.name: Cotinine: a potential new therapeutic agent against Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: Of these nAChRs, the alpha7 receptors are considered to be ideal therapeutic targets for several neurological conditions, including AD, schizophrenia, and Parkinsonâs disease (PD) as well as tobacco addiction [6, 7].

citation.name: Cotinine: a potential new therapeutic agent against Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: Because decreased levels of these receptors have been found in AD brains [58], this reduction is considered to explain, at least in part, the cognitive deï¬cits in AD.

citation.name: Cotinine: a potential new therapeutic agent against Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: This concept, though still controversial, is supported by the fact that the level of soluble Abeta correlates better with dementia than does plaque burden in AD patients [101, 102].

citation.name: Cotinine: a potential new therapeutic agent against Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: Interestingly, the Akt/GSK3Î² pathway is stimulated by the alpha7 receptor, has roles inhibiting neuronal cell death, and is involved in promoting neuronal synaptic plasticity and long-term potentiation [53â55].

citation.name: Cotinine: a potential new therapeutic agent against Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: Positive modulation of the Î±7 nAChRs could also explain cotinineâs positive effect on neuronal survival because the activation of Akt stimulates pro-survival proteins (e.g., Bcl-2 and the transcription factor cAMP responsive element-binding protein [CREB; Ref. 11] and inhibits the pro-apoptotic protein c-Jun Nterminal kinase (JNK) via the activation of the apoptosis signalregulating kinase (Ask) [76, 77; Figure 2].

citation.name: Cotinine: a potential new therapeutic agent against Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: Furthermore, alpha7 nAChRs can favor synaptic plasticity and cognition by activating the protein kinases phosphoinositide-3 kinase [PI3K; Refs. 78, 79], Akt, extracellular signal-regulated kinase 1/2 (ERK1/2), and the transcription factor CREB, which participate in mediating the structural and molecular changes required for learning and memory processes [80, 81].

citation.name: Cotinine: a potential new therapeutic agent against Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: Interestingly, the Akt/GSK3Î² pathway is stimulated by the alpha7 receptor, has roles inhibiting neuronal cell death, and is involved in promoting neuronal synaptic plasticity and long-term potentiation [53â55].

citation.name: Cotinine: a potential new therapeutic agent against Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: The alpha7 and alpha4beta2 nAChR subtypes are the most abundant of the nicotinic receptors and are fundamental for mediating working memory and attention in mammals. These receptors are localized throughout the cortex, hippocampus, amygdala, hypothalamus, striatum, and other regions involved in these cognitive processes [13].

citation.name: Cotinine: a potential new therapeutic agent against Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: The alpha7 receptors are very important for mediating sensory gating, attention and learning, and memory, making them an ideal target to improve these cognitive functions.

citation.name: Cotinine: a potential new therapeutic agent against Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: The activation of PI3K heterodimers p85/p110 by the Î±7 receptor is triggered by the binding of p85 (the regulatory subunit) to phospho-tyrosyl proteins such as Fyn, which leads to the release of p110 [the catalytic subunit; Ref. 82].

citation.name: Cotinine: a potential new therapeutic agent against Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: The Î±7 receptors seem to have a clear role in mediating Arc gene expression, as an increase in levels of Arc mRNA were found in rats treated with the selective Î±7 receptor partial agonist SSR180711 [96].

citation.name: Cotinine: a potential new therapeutic agent against Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: Another current therapeutic approach aims to decrease glutamate excitotoxicity by blocking the N-methyl D-aspartate (NMDA) glutamate receptor using the receptor antagonist memantine.

citation.name: Cotinine: a potential new therapeutic agent against Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: A negative correlation between tobacco use and the incidence of AD has been reported [22].

citation.name: Cotinine: a potential new therapeutic agent against Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: Nicotine binds to Abeta, blocking its aggregation into ï¬brils and is thereby neuroprotective [23].

citation.name: Cotinine: a potential new therapeutic agent against Alzheimer's disease.

citation.name: Cotinine: a potential new therapeutic agent against Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: Nicotine also diminishes AD pathology in animal models of the disease [24, 25].

citation.name: Cotinine: a potential new therapeutic agent against Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: However, clinical studies that aimed to determine the efï¬cacy of nicotine against AD pathology have not shown a signiï¬cant effect of nicotine in enhancing memory [26, 27] but rather a clear positive effect on attention in AD [27] and PD patients [25, 28].

citation.name: Cotinine: a potential new therapeutic agent against Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: The positive effect of nicotine on attention has been mostly attributed to its agonistic stimulation of the nAChRs, which plays an important role in mediating memory and attention processes [29â31].

citation.name: Cotinine: a potential new therapeutic agent against Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: However, the failure of nicotine to improve memory in AD patients, its inherent toxicity, and the fact that it induces tachyphylaxis and addiction have discouraged its use in the clinical arena [32].

citation.name: Cotinine: a potential new therapeutic agent against Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: Speciï¬cally, it has been shown that cotinine prevented working and reference memory loss in a mouse model of AD (Tg6799) and prevented AÎ² aggregation in vitro as well as plaque deposition in vivo [33].

citation.name: Cotinine: a potential new therapeutic agent against Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: Speciï¬cally, it has been shown that cotinine prevented working and reference memory loss in a mouse model of AD (Tg6799) and prevented AÎ² aggregation in vitro as well as plaque deposition in vivo [33].

citation.name: Cotinine: a potential new therapeutic agent against Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: In addition to its mnemonic qualities, cotinine has anti-AÎ² aggregation properties that add to its value as a new treatment for AD [33].

citation.name: Cotinine: a potential new therapeutic agent against Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: The pro-cognitive effect of cotinine in the Tg6799 mice may be explained by the reduction in the level of the aggregated forms of AÎ², including AÎ² plaques and oligomeric forms of the peptide, in the hippocampus and cortex [33].

citation.name: Cotinine: a potential new therapeutic agent against Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: Cotinine, is mostly metabolized by the liver to its major metabolites, trans-3âhydroxycotinine and its glucuronide [39â41].

citation.name: Cotinine: a potential new therapeutic agent against Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: More recently, we and other laboratories have found that cotinine is a memory enhancer in various animal models of disease.

citation.name: Cotinine: a potential new therapeutic agent against Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: Also, we recently published evidence showing that cotinine (5 mg/kg) decreased anxiety and enhanced the extinction of contextual fear memory after fear conditioning in wild type mice [50].

citation.name: Cotinine: a potential new therapeutic agent against Alzheimer's disease.

citation.name: Cotinine: a potential new therapeutic agent against Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: For instance, cotinine induced the activation of the pro-survival protein kinase B (Akt)/glycogen synthase kinase 3beta (GSK3beta) pathway in the brains of both Tg6799 and wild type control mice, suggesting that the activation of these factors is independent from its effect on AÎ² aggregation [33].

citation.name: Cotinine: a potential new therapeutic agent against Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: Contrary to this idea, new evidence shows that chronic treatment with cotinine stimulates the Akt/GSK3Î² pathway in the hippocampus and cortex of AD and control littermate mice [33].

citation.name: Cotinine: a potential new therapeutic agent against Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: Of equal importance, because GSK3Î² is considered to be one of the main tau kinases in vivo, the inhibition of GSK3Î² by cotinine may also prevent the abnormal phosphorylation of tau observed in AD brains and the consequent appearance of neuroï¬brillary tangles of hyperphosphorylated tau [85â87].

These receptors are localized throughout the cortex, hippocampus, amygdala, hypothalamus, striatum, and other regions involved in these cognitive processes [13].

citation.name: Cotinine: a potential new therapeutic agent against Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: The alpha7 and alpha4beta2 nAChR subtypes are the most abundant of the nicotinic receptors and are fundamental for mediating working memory and attention in mammals. These receptors are localized throughout the cortex, hippocampus, amygdala, hypothalamus, striatum, and other regions involved in these cognitive processes [13].

citation.name: Cotinine: a potential new therapeutic agent against Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: Because decreased levels of these receptors have been found in AD brains [58], this reduction is considered to explain, at least in part, the cognitive deï¬cits in AD.

citation.name: Cotinine: a potential new therapeutic agent against Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: In an attempt to improve the cognitive abilities of AD patients with this new approach, modulators of the Î±7 receptors, such as 3-(2,4-dimethoxybenzylidene) anabaseine (GTS-21 or DMXB-A) [56, 67, 68], and many others, are under development or are currently being investigated in clinical trials [56, 69â71].

citation.name: Cotinine: a potential new therapeutic agent against Alzheimer's disease.

citation.name: Cotinine: a potential new therapeutic agent against Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: Thus, PI3K stimulates the phosphorylation of Akt at residues threonine 308 and serine 473 [83]. The active form of Akt can then promote neuronal survival by stimulating CREB and Bcl-2 activity and by inactivating Ask1 by phosphorylation at serine 83 [84].

citation.name: Cotinine: a potential new therapeutic agent against Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: Furthermore, alpha7 nAChRs can favor synaptic plasticity and cognition by activating the protein kinases phosphoinositide-3 kinase [PI3K; Refs. 78, 79], Akt, extracellular signal-regulated kinase 1/2 (ERK1/2), and the transcription factor CREB, which participate in mediating the structural and molecular changes required for learning and memory processes [80, 81].

citation.name: Cotinine: a potential new therapeutic agent against Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: Furthermore, the stimulation of both CREB and ERK1/2 by cotinine may promote the expression of activity-regulated cytoskeleton-associated protein (Arc, also termed Arg3.1), derived from an immediate early gene required for the consolidation of memory [88â90].

citation.name: Cotinine: a potential new therapeutic agent against Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: Arc expression is stimulated by brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF), serum response element [91], NMDA receptors [92], elongation factor 2 [93], CREB, and ERK1/2 [94].

citation.name: Cotinine: a potential new therapeutic agent against Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: Positive modulation of the Î±7 nAChRs could also explain cotinineâs positive effect on neuronal survival because the activation of Akt stimulates pro-survival proteins (e.g., Bcl-2 and the transcription factor cAMP responsive element-binding protein [CREB; Ref. 11] and inhibits the pro-apoptotic protein c-Jun Nterminal kinase (JNK) via the activation of the apoptosis signalregulating kinase (Ask) [76, 77; Figure 2].
